Ezekiel & Bernheim,
Auctioneers,
Nos. 134 Main and 31 Hammond Streets.

Revd Dr. S. Morais
Philadelphia, Pa.
My valued Friend

The spring of thought has prompted me
to write you a few lines, a pleasure that I have not par-
taken of for a long time, it may be equally gratifying to
you for to know that you are not yet forgotten
I trust this may reach you finding your dear self &
your entire dear family in the enjoyment of health;
and I am pleased to chronicle that all of our family
are well thank God. I was in hopes to have wended
to y my way East ere this to have embraced the opportu-
nity of having a chat with you on our old topics.
I am aware that your mind if firmly fixed on the
success of the New York Jewish Theological Seminary
and I trust that you may accomplish all your antici-
pations, I hear but little of its progress. I really hope that
you may realize your most sanguine expectations, I do not
know how you can manage to educate boys for the
ministry without giving them subsistence and clothing
during the period of their education, we cannot,

some years ago we had several boys from wealthy
families who after spending a couple of years at
the college finally went into mercantile pursuits,
you must recollect, we had Freiburg, Marks, Friedlander
and others, it is only the poorest class that will re-
main with us and go through the entire course of study,
and there is no calculation to be made even with the
poorer class after they have been with us for a few
years and obtained a good secular education as
well collegiate and subsistance, they drop off. I think
the year that "Balisk" our last graduate entered our
College there was 15 entered his class with him and
all dropped off from time to time, so that he was the
only one graduated. doubtless you will have the
same difficulty to encounter from time to time. it
seems therefore a pity that there would be two rival
institutions to promote the same object of instruction; under
all those difficulties we have had to encounter, makes
me entertain the hopes that the day may not be far
distant when circumstances will permit, that an amal-
gamation will become a matter of necessity for your pupils
to complete there collegiate studies and obtain such Diploma
that will be recognized throughout the United States which
may tend to their benefit in obtaining lucrative posi-
tions. I have been considering these matters over and
over, and cannot help thinking of the advisability of
amalgamating these two institutions when a time

shall arrive when the benefit of my views may be-
come apparant through force of circumstances,
that may prove beneficial to the interest of Juda-
ism in this country, as a matter of course you as
well as myself are advancing in years of life, and
it may probably be well to interchange views on
this important subject in our time for the benefit
of those who may fill our void when God may be
pleased to call us away from this earthly abode.
My valued friend you know that I have never for
a moment doubted your honesty of purpose, at the
time you took hold of this affair. I am charitable
enough to say, that from your standpoint it must
have been galling enough to you at times, the va-
rious articles that emanated from the pen of
the President of this college in the "American Is-
raelite," still you konw that within the sacred pre-
cints[?] of the college, that that which is taught to
the students is from the same sources as you or
any other teacher would or could teach in any
Rabbinical College, and that Dr Wise or any
of the other teachers no matter how radical
their own private views are, they do not give
their opinions in opposition to the teachings
of our sages, hence why should any line be
drawn between the Eastern or Western College,
in the curriculum or course of study.

I just noted in this weeks Jewish Journals that
you have entered a few scholars in the higher
branches, did they advance from the lower
classes? or had they been taught the advance
studies before entering the Seminary, I can-
not well understand this part of it.

Now as regards our College, we are getting
on well, particularly with the rules adopted
by the Board of Governors and the Faculty, no doubt
you have read them in the "Am. Israelite" in
in the printed proceedings of the Board of Gover-
nors. We have about 45 students this session,
though will not graduate any this year, we
will launch them out the next however. We
intend to be very rigid with the students and
whenever requisite, will read the riot act to them
unsparingly, I have no doubt you will tire over
this [?], but I write as I feel and when the
spirit moves me. My sheet is full so God bless you and
all your dear ones with long life and health, and with
love to and from all. I remain as ever, yours truly
Jacob Ezekiel
